Gradient descent

This week's lab and homework explore the concept of machine learning as optimization, building on the lecture and lecture notes on margin maximization and gradient descent.

Group information

1) Explore gradient descent

We've established that machine learning problems can be posed as optimization problems. We begin by studying general strategies for finding the minimum of a function. In general, unless the function is convex, it may be computationally difficult to find its global minimum.

Note: A function is convex if the line segment between any two points on the graph of the function lies above or on the graph.

We will sometimes study convex objectives, but in other cases we will content ourselves with finding a local minimum (where the gradient is zero) which may not be a global minimum. One method to find a local minimum of a function is called gradient descent (there are better ways, but this one is simple and computationally efficient in high dimensions and with lots of data). The idea is that we start with an initial guess, x0x_0x0​, and move "downhill" in the direction of the gradient, leading to an update step

x(1)=x(0)−η∇xf(x(0))x^{(1)} = x^{(0)} - \eta \nabla_x f(x^{(0)})x(1)=x(0)−η∇x​f(x(0))
where η\etaη is a "step size" parameter with the constraint that η&gt;0\eta&gt; 0η>0. We continue updating until x(i+1)x^{(i+1)}x(i+1) does not differ too much from x(i)x^{(i)}x(i). This approach is guaranteed to find the minimum if the function is convex and η\etaη is sufficiently small.

The questions below are concerned with running gradient descent on the parabola

f(x)=(2x+3)2&ThickSpace;.f(x) = (2x + 3)^2\;.f(x)=(2x+3)2.

1A) Formulate the update rule that will be executed on every step when performing gradient descent on f(x)f(x)f(x). You may use eta and x in your Python expression, where eta represents η\etaη.

1C) This question asks you to explore convergence of gradient descent for our f(x)f(x)f(x), to see how the step size affects the rate of convergence and whether there are oscillations or lack of convergence.

We implement minimization of f(x)f(x)f(x) using a function t1, which runs gradient descent for the minimization of f(x)f(x)f(x). We halt the algorithm when the value of xxx changes by less than 10−510^{-5}10−5. In general, we may use some small tolerance such as this to say whether gradient descent has converged. Conversely, divergence is defined as being when xxx will not converge to a single finite value, even with an infinite number of updates.

When you click Submit, the tutor question generates a plot of f(x)f(x)f(x) in blue and the history of xxx values you have tried in red with a blue 'x' at the initial xxx value. You can change the values for step_size or init_val and click Submit again (all submits get 100%).

Experiment with the following step sizes: [0.01, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3]. For which one(s) does x(k)x^{(k)}x(k) converge without oscillation? For which one(s) does x(k)x^{(k)}x(k) diverge?

Why do oscillations happen for some values of step_size and not others? To gain insight into this behavior (and to understand how gradient descent proceeds), we note that we can rewrite our update rule:

x(k+1)=x(k)−η∇xf(x(k))x^{(k + 1)} = x^{(k)} - \eta \nabla_x f(x^{(k)})x(k+1)=x(k)−η∇x​f(x(k))
in the form:
z(k+1)=αz(k)&ThickSpace;&ThickSpace;z^{(k + 1)} = \alpha z^{(k)}\;\;z(k+1)=αz(k)
for some z=x−Cz = x - Cz=x−C, and then consider how or if zzz approaches 0 for large kkk (or equivalently, xxx approaches CCC for large kkk). In particular, this formulation will soon be useful for us to analyze how the step-size η\etaη affects convergence.



1D) Show that the gradient descent update rule for our function f(x)=(2x+3)2f(x) = (2x + 3)^2f(x)=(2x+3)2 can be written in the form:

x(k+1)+3/2=(1−8η)(x(k)+3/2)x^{(k+1)}+3/2=(1-8\eta)(x^{(k)}+3/2)x(k+1)+3/2=(1−8η)(x(k)+3/2)
and equivalently in the form
z(k+1)=αz(k)z^{(k + 1)} = \alpha z^{(k)}z(k+1)=αz(k)
by defining z(k)z^{(k)}z(k) and α\alphaα appropriately. What is z(k)z^{(k)}z(k) in terms of x(k)x^{(k)}x(k)? What is α\alphaα in terms of η\etaη?



Written in this form, we make the following key observation: we can think of our gradient descent step as simply a multiplication of the previous value by α\alphaα on each step.

Inductively, we can see that the value of zzz (and xxx) at step kkk is related to the initial value as

z(k)=αkz(0)z^{(k)} = \alpha^k z^{(0)}z(k)=αkz(0)
and equivalently
x(k)+3/2=(1−8η)k(x(0)+3/2)&ThickSpace;.x^{(k)}+3/2=(1-8\eta)^k(x^{(0)}+3/2)\;.x(k)+3/2=(1−8η)k(x(0)+3/2).

(Note: if this is not clear, please feel free to join the help queue.)

The above equations are useful because they explain the relationship between the initial value of zzz (or xxx) and the output of gradient descent as the repeated multiplication by the same factor α\alphaα on each step. From this, we can identify cases of convergence, oscillation, and divergence by the following values on α\alphaα:

α&gt;1\alpha &gt; 1α>1 Gradient descent diverges without oscillation; z→∞z \rightarrow \inftyz→∞
α=1\alpha = 1α=1 z(k)=z(0)z^{(k)} = z^{(0)}z(k)=z(0), so no gradient descent steps occur
1&gt;α≥01 &gt; \alpha \geq 01>α≥0 α∞\alpha^{\infty}α∞ approaches 0, so gradient descent converges; z→0z \rightarrow 0z→0
0&gt;α&gt;−10 &gt; \alpha &gt; -10>α>−1 α∞\alpha^{\infty}α∞ approaches 0 while changing signs every step, so converges with some oscillation
α=−1\alpha = -1α=−1 At every step, the sign of zzz flips. Gradient descent oscillates between z(0)z^{(0)}z(0) and −z(0)-z^{(0)}−z(0) endlessly
−1&gt;α-1 &gt; \alpha−1>α Gradient descent diverges with oscillation, since zzz grows but the sign of zzz flips at every step

Since our ultimate goal is convergence, we are interested in the cases where ∣α∣&lt;1|\alpha| &lt; 1∣α∣<1.

We can use the rules above about α\alphaα to reason about how η\etaη affects convergence, given that α=1−8η\alpha = 1-8\etaα=1−8η.

2) Where to meet?

A group of friends is planning to host a baby shower over the weekend. They want to find a location for the party that minimizes the sum of squared distances from their houses to the location of the party. Assume for now that they can host the party at any location in the town.

Assuming that the friends live in a 1-dimensional town, solve the following problems:

2A) Pose this problem as an (unconstrained) optimization problem. Assume there are nnn friends and the iii-th friend is located at lil_ili​. Denote the location of the party by ppp. What is the objective as a function of ppp? Write it down.

2B) Compute the gradient (write down/show your computation). Where is it zero?

2C) Which of the following is true?

There is necessarily a unique location that minimizes the objective function
The optimization problem may have local minima that are not global minima
The party can be always be hosted in one of the houses without loss of optimality
There is necessarily a choice of step size that makes gradient descent converge with oscillations for this problem
100.00%
